title: Qianlong-Period Enamel Glass Vase Sells for HK$207 Million
text:
This truly extraordinary glass vase, enameled by imperial command of the Qianlong Emperor in the early years of his reign, sold for HK$207 million at Sotheby's.

Text size

A highly important enamel glass vase from the Qianlong Emperor period fetched HK$207 million (US$26 million) at a Sotheby’s auction in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

It had a presale estimate of over HK$200 million.

The vase was offered from the collection of Taiwanese tycoon Robert Tsao, founder and chairman of United Microelectronics Corp., Taiwan’s first semiconductor company. He acquired the vase for HK$24 million in 2000.

Enameled glass vessels in the Qianlong period, painted in Western styles with vibrant colors, were by far the most complex and demanding of all works of art commissioned at the Beijing Palace Workshops. The one from Tsao’s collection is the most successful of all surviving examples, Sotheby’s said.

The 18.2-centimeter tall vase is in the shape of a pouch, which in Chinese is a homophone of “a package of luck and fortune.” The vase features a pink sash at the neck; a pair of phoenix soaring amid clouds and peonies, one bud with the blue-enamel mark; and a four-character seal mark reading "Qianlong Nianzhi” (which means “made in the Qianlong period”).

The exceptionally rare blue-and-white "dragon" stem bowl from Xuande period sells for HK$75 million at Sotheby's. Courtesy of Sotheby's

Another highlight at Sotheby’s sale of Chinese works of art on Oct. 8 is the blue-and-white “Dragon” stem bowl offered from the collection of Alan Chuang, chairman of Hong Kong-based investment firm Chuang’s Consortium.

The bowl, from the Ming Dynasty Xuande period (1426-1435), is painted in rich cobalt-blue tones with a pair of scaly five-clawed dragons soaring sinuously, one with its head turned back, the other with its head looking forward.

The bowl achieved HK$75 million, against a presale estimate of HK$60 million.
